How LinkedIn passed $2bn in subscription revenue

And they’re still missing out on their potential

This year, LinkedIn hit a record $2 billion in Premium subscriptions revenue — a 50% increase in just two years. Wow.

Not only that, but the free platform is performing strong, with 1 billion users across 200 countries and an increasing engagement year on year — comments alone are up 37%.

Why this is interesting: for many companies, mature = plateaued. But LinkedIn’s growth suggests otherwise.

Once you’ve hit a ceiling as a mature company, growing again is hard.
Typically, you need to:

  • Reconnect with your core ICP if you’ve drifted
  • Expand to adjacent ICPs
  • Enter new markets or verticals
  • Expand pricing tiers or paywall models
  • Improve engagement/frequency with new features
  • Buy other companies/join forces (i.e. Mergers & acquisitions, M&A)

So, the question is: How did LinkedIn manage to grow again — without dramatically changing who it serves?

Their official line: features — especially AI.
